body_html:
1-You usually need "sudo" to run pip installations, unless you are running inside a virtualenv.

2-There is also a problem where if you both have macOS installed python and brew installed python, you can install any packages on one, but run the other. MacOS installed python resides in /usr/bin/python while brew installs it under /usr/local/bin/python.
I think you need to run the following to make your system default to the brew installed python.
brew link python.
But SIP (System Integrity Protection) on macOS may complicate things.

Therefore I suggest you to create a virtualenv and install everything under that.
It should have no performance implications at all.
Also, any python environment changes you need will all be in a single folder, owned by you with no need for extra privileges.

1-You usually need "sudo" to run pip installations, unless you are running inside a virtualenv.

2-There is also a problem where if you both have macOS installed python and brew installed python, you can install any packages on one, but run the other. MacOS installed python resides in `/usr/bin/python` while brew installs it under `/usr/local/bin/python`.
I think you need to run the following to make your system default to the brew installed python.
`brew link python`.
But SIP (System Integrity Protection) on macOS may complicate things.

Therefore I suggest you to create a virtualenv and install everything under that.
It should have no performance implications at all.
Also, any python environment changes you need will all be in a single folder, owned by you with no need for extra privileges.
